content.text: A **truth table** systematically shows all possible truth values for a compound proposition. By listing every combination of truth values for the atomic propositions, we can compute the truth value of any complex formula.

content.title: Truth Table for Conjunction (∧)
content.note: Conjunction is true ONLY when both conjuncts are true.

content.title: Truth Table for Disjunction (∨)
content.note: Disjunction is false ONLY when both disjuncts are false.

content.definition: A formula that is true in ALL rows of its truth table. Example: P ∨ ¬P (law of excluded middle).
A formula that is false in ALL rows of its truth table. Example: P ∧ ¬P.
A formula that is true in some rows and false in others. Most ordinary statements are contingent.

content.question: What is a tautology?
options: A statement that is always false
A statement that is sometimes true
A statement that is always true
A statement with no truth value
content.explanation: A tautology is a formula that is true in every row of its truth table — it's true regardless of the truth values of its component propositions.
